channel.title: Communities | Dr. Luz Angélica Caudillo Mata

item.title: 17th ACM International Conference on Web Search and Data Mining (WSDM 2024)
item.description:
Role:

  • General Chair ACM WSDM 2024

Main Activities:

  • Leadership and vision. Together with my two co-general chairs, we set the overarching vision for WSDM 2024, defining conference goals that aligned with the WSDM community.
  • Planning and coordination. Together with with my two co-general chairs, we oversaw the coordination of 40+ organizing members across various subcommittees responsible for different areas such as technical program, workshops, tutorials, industry day, doctoral consortium, WSDM day, WSDM cup, WSDM virtual, WSDM proceedings, sponsorship, publicity, website, volunteers, and local logistics.
  • Committee management. Together with with my two co-general chairs, we assembled and managed an international, diverse, and high-caliber conference committee of 36 members, ensuring that all of them were aligned with the conference’s goals and deadlines.
  • Budget management. Responsible for the financial planing of the conference, which included creating and managing the budget, overseeing registration fees, and ensuring financial viability.
  • Venue and Vendor negotiation. Alongside with one of my co-general chairs, we oversaw the selection of the conference venue and the negotiation of contracts with various service providers.
  • Sponsorship and funding. Contributed to secure sponsorship and funding from institutions in Latin America interested in supporting the conference.
  • Publicity and public relations. Alongide with the PR committee, we developed and implemented strategies for promoting the conference to attract attendees and submissions, and enhanced the conference’s visibility and impact within the community. Additionally, I contributed to liaising between the WSDM conference and stakeholders in Mexico and Latin America, fostering local engagement and support.
  • Program oversight. Together with my two co-general chairs, we supported our program chairs to ensures the conference’s technical program was of high quality, relevant, and well-organized.
  • Crisis management. Addressed challenges and managed crises effectively, which was especially important in the context of hosting the conference in a new location (Mexico) for the first time.
  • Promoting diversity and inclusion. Together with my two co-general chairs, we actively promoted diversity and inclusion, focusing on making the conference accessible and welcoming to a wide range of participants from different backgrounds and regions in Latin America.
  • Volunteer selection. Alongside local logistics committee, we recruited and selected 20 local volunteers, ensuring a team well equipped to support the diverse needs of the conference.
  • Post-conference activities. Engaged in post-conference activities such as gathering feedback, closing budget, and providing insights, which are crucial for documenting the successes and learning points of hosting the conference in a new region.

Period:

  • November 2022 - December 2024

item.title: 5th International Meeting of Artificial Intelligence and Its Applications (RIIAA 5.0)
item.description:
Roles:

  • Chair of RIIAA Virtual, which is the virtual complement to the in-person RIIAA chapters in Mexicy City and Quito, Ecuador. RIIAA virtual is held from Sep 28 to 29, 2022.
  • Co-chair of the Community Circles (CIRCOS) Sessions.
  • Member of the RIIAA Board of Directors.

Main Activities:

  • Design plan and program for RIIAA Virtual.
  • Coordinate of a team of 6 volunteers to execute plan to run RIIAA Virtual.
  • Coordinate and collaborate with 2 other co-chairs to run the CIRCOS sessions within the RIIAA program.
    • Video playlists of these sessions can be seen on buttons at the top.

Period:

  • March 2022 - November 2022

item.title: Community of Practice on Machine Learning System Design

This community of practice is organized within the Geointelligence Engineering Department at MDA.

Description:
Working group of engineers (software, systems) and product developers that shares best practices and knowledge on Machine Learning System Design in the context of next-generation Geointelligence products and services.

Roles:

  • Founder
  • Co-organizer
  • Facilitator

item.title: 4th International Meeting of Artificial Intelligence and Its Applications (RIIAA 4.0)
item.description:
Roles:

  • Chair of the Panels & Community Circles Sessions.

Main Activities:

  • Coorditor of a team of 13 volunteers to execute the technical program of the virtual conference, and to facilitate the participation of 133 speakers. The technical program consisted of 6 panels and 17 CIRCOS.
    • Video playlists of these sessions can be seen on buttons at the top.
  • Contributed to edit post: RIIAA 4.0 is here!
  • Contributed to edit post: RIIAA - Catalyzing Artificial Intelligence in LATAM.

Period:

  • March 2021 - November, 2021

item.title: RIIAA 2021: AI Demos Showcase Panel
item.description:
This panel was held as part of the technical program of the 4th International Meeting of Artificial Intelligence and Its Applications (RIIAA) .

Role:

  • Co-organizer

Abstract:

The AI demo showcase session features demos from across different areas of AI. This session is particularly focused on showcasing the power of state-of-the-art AI technology being applied to different domains, such as robotics, speech, and predictive coding. The session provides a lens into how AI is transforming our world for the benefit of humankind.

item.title: AAAI 2021: LatinXperiences Workshop
item.description:
This workshop was one of the accepted diversity and inclusion activities at the AAAI-21 conference.

Roles:

  • Co-organizer
  • Facilitator

Abstract:

LatinXperiences is an event that strives to create new and lasting connections between established researchers, at top-tier universities and research laboratories, and early-career researchers and students from Latin American countries.

There are thriving research and tech communities in Latin America that, for the most part, do not interact with the AAAI community. Our goal is to bring these communities together in a welcoming, social environment.

item.title: BIRS's CIH Program 2020: Making a Career Transition Into Industry in AI Panel
item.description:
This panel was celebrated as part of the Career & Innovation Hub Program co-organized by the Banff International Research Station (BIRS) and other leading Canadian Mathematical institutions.

Roles:

  • Organizer
  • Facilitator
  • Speaker

Abstract:
In this panel, alumni of graduate programs in mathematics, computer science, and statistics share how they successfully transitioned from academia into industrial positions in the areas of machine learning, AI, and data science. After learning from the story of each of our four panelists, we’ll have an extensive Q&A session.

item.title: 3rd International Meeting of Artificial Intelligence and Its Applications (RIIAA 3.0)
item.description:
Roles:

  • Organizing committee member.
  • Co-founder and coordinator of program Community Circles (CIRCOS).
  • Contributor to transition meeting to a virtual format.

Period:

  • April, 2020 - September, 2020

item.title: Community Circles (CIRCOS) Program
item.description:
Community Circles (CIRCOS) Program

Roles:

  • Co-founder
  • Co-Chair
  • Program Coordinator

Period:
2020-05-01 to Present

Description:

The Community Circles (CIRCOS) is an innitiative first launched in the context of the 3rd International Meeting of Artificial Intelligence and Its Applications (RIIAA 2020) – virtual edition. The CIRCOS initiative was first proposed by Benjamín Sánchez Lengeling and myself. Since 2021, Andrés Muños Medina is also part of the CIRCOS team.

CIRCOS are a collaborative space, celebrated annually within the RIIAA conference, where actors from different sectors (e.g., academia, industry, government, etc.) and disciplines (e.g., computer scientists, mathematicians, chemists, etc.) can exchange ideas, knowledge and perspectives in topics of common interest related to the field of artificial intelligence.

Such collaborative spaces take the form of parallel, interactive, informal, and self-organized sessions. Each session is referred to as a CIRCO. The topics discussed in the sessions may be directly or indirectly related to the topics discussed in RIIAA.

In CIRCOS, the community proposes the topics to be discussed in each emission of the program. It is a community program for the community!

Main Activities:

  • Proposed and implemented the CIRCOS program as part of RIIAA 2020.
  • Oversee general coordination and logistics of the program execution since 2020.
  • Coordinate team of volunteers.

CIRCOS 2022 in numbers:

  • 9 CIRCOS, 35 speakers.
    • This is the first time CIRCOS sessions were held in the three RIIAA modalities. We had 5 CIRCOS remote in RIIAA Virtual, 2 CIRCOS in-person in RIIAA Mexico City, and 2 CIRCOS in-person in RIIAA Quito.
  • CIRCOS 2022 program.

CIRCOS 2021 in numbers:

  • 17 CIRCOS, 94 speakers.
  • CIRCOS 2021 program.
  • CIRCOS video playlist.

CIRCOS 2020 in numbers:

  • 8 CIRCOS, 39 speakers.
  • CIRCOS 2020 program.
  • Video CIRCO: Centros de IA en México

Abstract
The purpose of this panel is to show participants of the summer school the diverse applications and paths that a STEM degree leads to.

item.title: Science Leadership & Management (SLAM) Workshop Series
AGU 2017: Open Source Software in the Geosciences Panel
item.description:
This panel was held as part of the technical program of the 2017 American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting.

Role:

  • Co-organizer

Abstract:
This panel discusses open-source software and explore its interaction with the wider scientific community: What are motivating factors for developing open-source software? What are examples of its impacts?

There are questions about the implementation and functioning of an open-source community: How do developers engage with the community? How are new contributors/users on-boarded? What lessons can you offer to those who are involved in other open-source initiatives?

Attribution for software contributions is an immature topic that is particularly important for early-career scientists and relevant to tenure track, hiring, and proposal review panels. How should the scientific community recognize these contributions?

Wrestling with these questions is perhaps one of the main reasons why open-source products are still relatively rare; we explore these questions in the panel discussion.

item.title: MCA 2017: Computational Inverse Problems: from Multiscale Modeling to Uncertainty Quantification Symposium
item.description:
Special session (minysimposium) held as part of the Mathematical Congress of the Americas 2017.

Roles:

  • Co-organizer
  • Speaker

Period:

  • July, 2016 to August 2017

Abstract:
Computational inverse problems are prevalent and essential in various scientific and industrial applications, ranging from biomedical and geophysical imaging to computer vision and neuroscience. For example, in many physical systems, measurements are obtained on the exterior of an object (e.g., the human body or the earth’s crust), and they are used with the goal of estimating the internal structure(s) or physical properties of such object.

Currently, the main challenges in the field of inverse problems are (1) the affordable computation of the forward model, especially for models with multiple length-scale features, (2) the efficient and reliable computation of solutions to inverse problems, and (3) the development of statistical methods to validate model assumptions and inversion estimates. Sophisticated tools from statistics, numerical optimization, numerical linear algebra, and multiscale analysis are required to address these challenges.

The goal of this special session is to gather a diverse and accomplished pool of experts working in the active and thriving research area of computational inverse problems who will present an overview of the state of-the-art methods to address the key challenges discussed. For example, speakers will present on new nonlinear optimization approaches, novel regularization techniques, iterative reconstruction techniques (e.g., hybrid methods and preconditioners), methods for statistical validation and uncertainty quantification, and the progress on multiscale methods and their applications within an inversion procedure.

  • Conference Program

item.title: SIAM CSE17: Reduced Models and Multiscale Methods Symposium
item.description:
Minisymposium held as part of the SIAM Conference on Computational Science and Engineering (CSE17).

Roles:

  • Co-organizer
  • Speaker

Period:

  • August, 2016 - March, 2017

Abstract:
Accurate and efficient simulations of physical responses in large-scale heterogeneous media is crucial to search and image geological formations in a wide range of geophysical applications, including mineral and hydrocarbon exploration, water resource utilizations, and geothermal power extractions. One major challenge in practice to perform this type of simulations is the excessive computational cost it involves.

In this mini symposium, consisting of two parts, we explore ways to reduce the complexity and the cost of the simulation by introducing multiscale and upscaling methods as well as reduce space modeling.

  • Mini Symposium Part I
  • Mini Symposium Part II

item.title: Scientific Computing, Applied, and Industrial Mathematics (SCAIM) Seminar Series
item.description:
The Scientific Computing, Applied and Industrial Mathematics (SCAIM) Seminar is an interdepartmental seminar at the University of British Columbia (UBC) focused on research in scientific computing, industrial and applied mathematics, mathematical modelling, and computational science.

The audience for the talks are typically faculty members and graduate students from the departments of Computer Science, Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences, Mathematics, Mechanical Engineering, and Physics & Astronomy. The speakers are researchers from UBC or other institutions.

The seminar was held every 2 weeks.

Role:

  • Co-organizer
  • Facilitator

Period:

  • September 1st, 2014 to June 30th, 2016
  • Organized 34 seminars

Seminars:

  • SCAIM Seminars Series 2014-2015
  • SCAIM Seminars Series 2015-2016
